revision.text:
{{About|physician qualifications and titles in the United States||DO (disambiguation)}} {{For|the restricted-scope form of [[alternative medicine]] practice, mostly outside of North America|Osteopathy}} {{Further|Osteopathic medicine in the United States}} {{Osteopathic medicine}} '''Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine''' ('''DO''' or '''D.O.''') is a professional [[doctoral degree]] for [[physician]]s and [[surgeon]]s offered by [[Medical school in the United States|medical schools]] in the [[United States]]. A DO graduate may become licensed as an [[Osteopathic medicine in the United States|osteopathic physician]], having equivalent rights, privileges, and responsibilities as a [[physician]] who has earned the [[Doctor of Medicine]] (MD) degree.<ref name="Medline" /> DO physicians are licensed to practice the full scope of [[medicine]] and [[surgery]] in 65 countries,<ref name="AroundWorld">{{cite web |url=http://www.osteopathic.org/osteopathic-health/about-dos/dos-around-the-world/Pages/default.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120906011238/http://www.osteopathic.org/osteopathic-health/about-dos/dos-around-the-world/Pages/default.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 September 2012 |title=DOs Around the World |publisher=American Osteopathic Association |accessdate=12 June 2013 }}</ref> and in all 50 US states. They constitute 7% of all US physicians. As of 2017, there were more than 137,000 osteopathic medical physicians and osteopathic medical students in the United States.<ref name=OMP2015>{{cite web |title=Osteopathic Medical Profession Report |url=http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/about/aoa-annual-statistics/Documents/2016-OMP-report.pdf |accessdate=2017-05-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629180616/http://osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/about/aoa-annual-statistics/Documents/2016-OMP-report.pdf |archive-date=2017-06-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
DO degrees are offered in the United States at 34 [[Medical school in the United States|medical schools]], at 51 campuses in 32<ref>American Osteopathic Association 2017 Statistics</ref> states,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aacom.org/about/colleges/Pages/default.aspx|title=U.S. Colleges of Osteopathic Medicine|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=AACOM|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref> compared to MD degrees offered at 140 schools.<ref>[http://www.lcme.org/directry.htm Directory of Accredited Medical Education Programs, Liaison Committee on Medical Education] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/60MHPlzyM?url=http://www.lcme.org/directry.htm |date=2011-07-22 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.aamc.org/about/medicalschools/ |title=AAMC Medical Schools |accessdate=2006-12-13 |publisher=Association of American Medical Colleges |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812102623/https://www.aamc.org/about/medicalschools/ |archivedate=2013-08-12 |df= }}</ref> Since 2007, total DO student enrollment has been increasing yearly. In 2015, more than 20% of all medical school enrollment in the US comprised DO students.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Berger|first1=Joseph|title=The D.O. Is in Now. Osteopathic Schools Turn Out Nearly a Quarter of All Med School Grads|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/03/education/edlife/the-osteopathic-branch-of-medicine-is-booming.html?_r=0|accessdate=11 November 2014|agency=NY Times|issue=ED14|date=14 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/about/aoa-annual-statistics/Pages/osteopathic-medical-schools.aspx |title=OMP Report: Osteopathic Medical Schools |publisher=American Osteopathic Association |accessdate=January 26, 2016}}</ref> The curricula at [[Osteopathic medicine in the United States|osteopathic]] medical schools are [[Comparison of MD and DO in the United States|similar to those at MD-granting medical schools]], which focus the first two years on the [[biomedical]] and [[clinical medicine|clinical]] sciences, then two years on [[Clerkship (medicine)|core clinical training]] in the clinical specialties.<ref name="Harrisons">{{cite book|author=Kasper, Dennis L.|author2=Eugene Braunwald|author3=Anthony S. Fauci|author4=Stephen L. Hauser|author5=Dan L. Longo|author6=J. Larry Jameson|author7=Kurt J. Isselbacher|title=Harrison's principles of internal medicine|chapter=Chapter 10. Complementary and Alternative Medicine|date=2004|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=New York|isbn=978-0071391405|edition=16th}}</ref>
Upon completing medical school, a DO graduate may enter an [[Internship (medicine)|internship]] or [[Residency (medicine)|residency]] training program, which may be followed by [[Fellowship (medicine)|fellowship training]].<ref name="Harrisons" /> Some<!-- I could find no indication in the references of "many", nor any percentage of, DO enrollment at, or graduation from, graduate medical schools --> DO graduates attend the same [[graduate medical education]] programs as their MD counterparts,<ref name="ACGME_Data2011">{{cite web|title=Graduate Medical Education Data Resource Book: 2011-12|pages=5, 6, 59, 60|url=http://www.acgme.org/acgmeweb/Portals/0/PFAssets/PublicationsBooks/2011-2012_ACGME_DATABOOK_DOCUMENT_Final.pdf|publisher=Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> and then take MD specialty board exams,<ref name="RoadmaptoResidency">{{cite web |url=https://members.aamc.org/eweb/upload/Roadmap%20to%20Residency%202ndEd.pdf |title=Roadmap to Residency: From Application to the Match and Beyond |date=2007 |publisher=Association of American Medical Colleges |accessdate=June 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201203006/https://members.aamc.org/eweb/upload/Roadmap%20to%20Residency%202ndEd.pdf |archivedate=February 1, 2014 |df= }}</ref> while other DO graduates enter osteopathic programs,<ref name="AOAapprovedResidency">{{cite web|title=AOA Approved Internships and Residencies|url=http://opportunities.osteopathic.org/search/search.cfm?searchType=1&CFID=330437&CFTOKEN=3530e0b5898fbb31-B95CDBA2-A2EC-0D67-3E32D221E7359244&jsessionid=f0302129dec368e56de2113162c122d3d357|publisher=American Osteopathic Association|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="The DO">{{cite web|url=http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/accreditation/opti-approval/Documents/list-of-affiliated-partner-hospitals.pdf |title=Opportunities, Directory of Osteopathic Postdoctoral Education Programs, Supplemental OPTI Affiliation List |date=October 2010 |publisher=''[[The DO]]'' |accessdate=June 28, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and take DO specialty board examinations.<ref name="SpecialtyCertBoards">{{cite web|title=AOA Specialty Certifying Boards|url=http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/development/aoa-board-certification/Pages/aoa-specialty-boards.aspx/|publisher=American Osteopathic Association|accessdate=19 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120601001928/http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/development/aoa-board-certification/Pages/aoa-specialty-boards.aspx|archive-date=2012-06-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
One notable difference between DO and [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] training is that DO training adds 300–500 hours studying techniques for hands-on manipulation of the [[human musculoskeletal system]],<ref name="Medline" /><ref name=understanding/> a system shared (in general but not all particulars) with [[chiropractic medicine]].
== History == {{further|Osteopathic medicine in the United States#History}}
The practice of [[osteopathy]] began in the United States in 1874. The term "osteopathy" was coined by physician and surgeon<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/atsu&CISOPTR=693&REC=1 |title=''Medical Registration for Macon County, MO as of March 27, 1874,'' Missouri Digital Heritage, Secretary of State of Missouri |accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://cdm.sos.mo.gov/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/atsu&CISOPTR=759&CISOBOX=1&REC=2 |title=Medical registration for Adair County, MO dated 28 July 1883 |publisher=Missouri Digital Heritage, Secretary of State of Missouri}}</ref> [[Andrew Taylor Still]], who named his new discipline of medicine "osteopathy", reasoning that "the bone, ''osteon'', was the starting point from which [he] was to ascertain the cause of pathological conditions".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.meridianinstitute.com/eamt/files/webster1/webcont.html#HOW%20I%20CAME%20TO%20ORIGINATE%20OSTEOPATHY |title=Early American Manual Therapy |access-date=2013-10-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205145639/http://meridianinstitute.com/eamt/files/webster1/webcont.html#HOW%20I%20CAME%20TO%20ORIGINATE%20OSTEOPATHY |archive-date=2010-12-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Still founded the American School of Osteopathy (now [[A.T. Still University]] of the Health Sciences) in [[Kirksville, Missouri|Kirksville]], Missouri, for the teaching of osteopathy on May 10, 1892. While the state of Missouri granted the right to award the MD degree,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.gov/highereducation/AGMEC/osteopathic_med_school_accreditation_standards.pdf |title=Commission on Osteopathic College Accreditation |publisher=State of New Jersey |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908041004/http://www.nj.gov/highereducation/AGMEC/osteopathic_med_school_accreditation_standards.pdf |archivedate=2008-09-08 |df= }}</ref> he remained dissatisfied with the limitations of conventional medicine and instead chose to retain the distinction of the DO degree.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://history.osteopathic.org/educate.shtml |title=Osteopathic Virtual Museum |accessdate=13 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316164329/http://history.osteopathic.org/educate.shtml |archivedate=16 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> In 1898 the American Institute of Osteopathy started the ''[[Journal of Osteopathy]]'' and by that time four states recognized the profession.<ref>{{cite journal|title=General Notices|journal=Popular Science Monthly|date=Mar 1898|page=710|url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/20879097|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref>
The osteopathic medical profession has evolved into two branches: non-physician manual medicine [[osteopathy|osteopaths]], who were educated and trained outside the United States; and US-trained osteopathic physicians, who conduct a full scope of medical practice. The regulation of non-physician manual medicine osteopaths varies greatly between jurisdictions. In the United States, osteopathic physicians holding the DO degree have attained the same rights, privileges, and responsibilities as [[physicians]] with a [[Doctor of Medicine]] (MD) degree.<ref name=Medline /> Osteopathic physicians and non-physician osteopaths are so distinct that in practice they function as separate professions.
As originally conceived by Andrew Still, the letters "DO" stood for "Diplomate in Osteopathy" and the title conferred by the degree was "Doctor of Osteopathy".<ref name="Booth2006">{{cite book|author=Emmons Rutledge Booth|title=History of Osteopathy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jg6jQzKegQQC&pg=PA80|date=2006|isbn=978-3-936679-04-5|page=80}}</ref> Subsequently, the degree also came to be entitled "Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine".<ref name="DiGiovannaSchiowitz2005">{{cite book|author1=Eileen L. DiGiovanna|author2=Stanley Schiowitz|author3=Dennis J. Dowling|title=An Osteopathic Approach to Diagnosis and Treatment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tot78_5FxZwC&pg=PA3|date=2005|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-0-7817-4293-1|page=3}}</ref> Since the late 20th century, the AOA has preferred that this title be used exclusively.<ref name="brand">{{cite web|url=http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/news-and-publications/media-center/Pages/osteopathic-style-guide.aspx|title=Terminology for Reporting on Osteopathic Medicine|accessdate=6 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514135333/http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/news-and-publications/media-center/Pages/osteopathic-style-guide.aspx|archive-date=2013-05-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Its members resolved at a 1960 conference:
{{quote|Be it resolved, that the American Osteopathic Association institute a policy, both officially in our publications and individually on a conversational basis, to use the terms osteopathic medicine in place of the word osteopathy and osteopathic physician and surgeon in place of osteopath; the words osteopathy and osteopath being reserved for historical, sentimental, and informal discussions only.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=8244784|date=1993|last1=Allen|first1=TW|title='Osteopathic physician' defines our identity|volume=93|issue=9|pages=884|journal=The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association}}</ref>}}
A minority of DOs continue to use the old terms, and the [[American Academy of Osteopathy]] retains the old usage in its name.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=21178160|date=2010|last1=Allen|first1=TW|title=Osteopathic medical terminology--redux|volume=110|issue=12|pages=743–4|journal=The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association}}</ref>
==Demographics== In 2015, there were 96,954 osteopathic [[physicians|medical doctors]] in the United States and 123,075 total DOs and osteopathic medical students.<ref name="OMP2015"/> The proportion of females in the profession has steadily increased since the 1980s.<ref name=OMP_2012 /> In 1985, about 10 percent of DO physicians were female, compared with 40 percent in 2015.<ref name=OMP_2015>{{cite web|title=Osteopathic Medicine Profession Report 2015|url=http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/about/aoa-annual-statistics/Documents/2015-OMP-report.pdf|publisher=American Osteopathic Association|access-date=2016-01-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201133749/http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/about/aoa-annual-statistics/Documents/2015-OMP-report.pdf|archive-date=2016-02-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Between 2008 and 2012, 49 percent of new DO graduates were females.<ref name=OMP_2012>{{cite web|title=Osteopathic Medical Profession Report 2012|url=http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/about/aoa-annual-statistics/Documents/2012-OMP-report.pdf|publisher=American Osteopathic Association|access-date=2012-12-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616054507/http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/about/aoa-annual-statistics/Documents/2012-OMP-report.pdf|archive-date=2013-06-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
During the 2011-12 academic year, the osteopathic medical student body consisted of: 69 percent white/non-Hispanic, 19 percent Asian or Pacific Islander, 3.5 percent Hispanic, 3 percent African-American, and 0.5 percent Native American or Alaskan.<ref name=OMP_2012 /> The remainder were listed as "other or not entered". The five-year change in osteopathic medical student enrollment by ethnicity has increased by 19 percent for white/non-Hispanic students, 36 percent for Asian-American students, 24 percent for Black/African American students and 60 percent for Hispanic/Latino students.<ref name=OMP_2015 />
==Education, training and distinctiveness == {{further|Osteopathic medicine in the United States|Osteopathic manipulative medicine}} Osteopathic medical school curricula are virtually identical to those at schools granting the MD degree ([[Doctor of Medicine]]). Once admitted to an osteopathic medical school, students study for four years in order to graduate. The schooling is divided into the pre-clinical and clinical years. The pre-clinical years, the first and second years, focus on the biomedical and clinical sciences. The clinical years, the third and fourth years, consist of [[Clerkship (medicine)|core clinical training]] and [[sub-internship]]s in the clinical specialties.
Osteopathic medical school accreditation standards require training in [[internal medicine]], [[Obstetrics and gynaecology|obstetrics/gynecology]], [[pediatrics]], [[family medicine]], [[surgery]], [[psychiatry]], [[emergency medicine]], [[radiology]], [[preventive medicine]], and [[public health]].<ref name=curriculum>{{cite web|title=Overview of Osteopathic Medical Education/Accreditation/The Four-Year Curriculum (2012 Osteopathic Medical College Information Book) |url=http://www.aacom.org/resources/bookstore/cib/Documents/2012cib/2012cib-p8.pdf |publisher=American Association of Colleges of Osteopathic Medicine|date=2012}}</ref> According to [[Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine]], "the training, practice, credentialing, licensure, and reimbursement of osteopathic physicians is virtually indistinguishable from those of physicians with MD qualifications, with 4 years of osteopathic medical school followed by specialty and subspecialty training and [[board certification]]".<ref name=Harrisons />
DO schools provide an additional 300–500 hours in the study of hands-on manual medicine and the body's musculoskeletal system, which is referred to as [[osteopathic manipulative medicine]] (OMM).<ref name=Medline>{{cite web|url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/002020.htm |title=Doctor of Osteopathic medicine (D.O.) |author=MedLine Plus |date=2007 |work=National Institutes of Health |publisher=U.S. National Library of Medicine, National Institutes of Health |accessdate=June 28, 2012}}</ref> Historically, osteopaths subscribed to the view that such body manipulation can bring about systemic healing – a belief which is a form of pseudomedicine. In the early 21st century, American osteopathic physicians have largely shifted their thinking from such pre-scientific ideas.<ref name=understanding>{{cite book |author=Swanson ES |title=Science and Society: Understanding Scientific Methodology, Energy, Climate, and Sustainability |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tQmhCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA65 |year=2015 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-3-319-21987-5 |page=65 |chapter=Pseudoscience}}</ref>
Osteopathic physicians who use OMM predominantly use it to treat musculoskeletal conditions, for which there is [[Osteopathic manipulative medicine#effectiveness|conflicting evidence]] about effectiveness.<ref name="Franke2014">{{Cite journal|vauthors=Franke H, Franke JD, Fryer G |title=Osteopathic manipulative treatment for nonspecific low back pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis |journal=BMC Musculoskelet Disord|volume=15|issue=1|pages=286|date=August 2014|pmid=25175885|pmc=4159549|doi=10.1186/1471-2474-15-286|type=Systematic review & meta-analysis}}</ref><ref name=chronic>{{cite journal |vauthors=Orrock PJ, Myers SP |title=Osteopathic intervention in chronic non-specific low back pain: a systematic review |journal=BMC Musculoskelet Disord |volume=14 |issue= |pages=129 |year=2013 |pmid=23570655 |pmc=3623881 |doi=10.1186/1471-2474-14-129 |type=Systematic review}}</ref> Particular criticism has been targeted at [[craniosacral therapy]], a component of OMM taught at many DO schools, which has limited scientific support.<ref name="pmid23131379">{{cite journal |vauthors=Jäkel A, von Hauenschild P |title=A systematic review to evaluate the clinical benefits of craniosacral therapy |journal=Complement Ther Med |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=456–65 |year=2012 |pmid=23131379 |doi=10.1016/j.ctim.2012.07.009 |url=}}</ref><ref name="rev2012">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.2042-7166.2012.01174.x |title=Craniosacral therapy: A systematic review of the clinical evidence |year=2012 |author=Ernst E |journal=Focus on Alternative and Complementary Therapies |volume=17 |issue=4 |pages=197–201}}</ref>
===Examinations=== Before entering osteopathic medical school, an application must complete a four-year undergraduate degree and take a national standardized exam called the [[Medical College Admissions Test]] (MCAT). Some combined undergraduate/medical programs exist. Some authors note the differences in the average MCAT scores and [[grade point average]] of students who [[Matriculation|matriculate]] at DO schools compared to those who matriculate at MD schools within the United States. In 2015, the average MCAT and GPA for students entering US-based MD programs were 31.4 and 3.70, respectively,<ref>{{cite web|title=Table 17: MCAT Scores and GPAs for Applicants and Matriculants to U.S. Medical Schools |url=https://www.aamc.org/download/161690/data/table17.pdf |publisher=Association of American Medical Colleges |date=2000–2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614143734/https://www.aamc.org/download/161690/data/table17.pdf |archivedate=2012-06-14 |df= }}</ref> and 27.33 and 3.55 for DO matriculants,<ref name=2011_MatriculantProfile>{{cite web|title=AACOMAS Matriculant Profile 2011 Entering Class |url=http://www.aacom.org/docs/default-source/data-and-trends/2012-15-matprofilerpt.pdf?sfvrsn=8 |format=PDF |publisher=American Association of Colleges of Osteopathic Medicine |accessdate=14 July 2012}}</ref> although the gap has been getting smaller every year.<ref name=2011_MatriculantProfile /> DO medical schools are more likely to accept non-traditional students,<ref>{{cite web|title=Osteopathic Medical College Information Book|url=http://www.aacom.org/resources/bookstore/cib/Documents/2012cib/2012cib-whole.pdf|publisher=American Association of Colleges of Osteopathic Medicine|date=2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Madison Park |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/06/13/mid.life.doctors/index.html?hpt=hp_t2/ |title=Never too late to be a doctor |publisher=CNN News |date=June 13, 2011 |accessdate=December 17, 2011}}</ref> who are older and entering medicine as a second career, or coming from non-science majors.
DO medical students are required to take the Comprehensive Osteopathic Medical Licensure Examination ([[COMLEX-USA]]), which is sponsored by the [[National Board of Osteopathic Medical Examiners]] (NBOME). The COMLEX-USA is series of four osteopathic medical licensing examinations. The first three exams of the COMLEX-USA are taken during medical school and are prerequisites for osteopathic residency programs, which are available in almost every specialty of medicine and surgery. Level 2 consists of a multiple-choice portion and a patient evaluation exam (2PE). COMLEX-Level 2PE, is available only in [[Chicago]], IL and [[Philadelphia]], PA. It is graded as a Pass/Fail exam. Finally, COMLEX Level 3 is taken during the first year of residency.
In addition to the COMLEX-USA, DO medical students may choose to sit for the MD licensure examinations, which are called the [[United States Medical Licensing Examination]] (USMLE).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmle.org/bulletin/eligibility/ |title=United States Medical Licensing Examination | USMLE Bulletin | Eligibility |publisher=Usmle.org |accessdate=2012-02-22}}</ref> This is typically done if the student desires to enter an MD residency. However, this is not always required, as some MD residency programs do not require the USMLE from DO applicants.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sarko|first=John|author2=Svoren, Elena |author3=Katz, Eric |title=COMLEX-1 and USMLE-1 Are Not Interchangeable Examinations|journal=Academic Emergency Medicine|date=February 2010|volume=17|issue=2|pages=218–220|doi=10.1111/j.1553-2712.2009.00632.x|pmid=20070273}}<!--|accessdate=19 November 2012--></ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Chick|first=Davoren A.|author2=Harley P. Friedman|author3=Vincent B. Young|author4=David Solomon|title=Relationship Between COMLEX and USMLE Scores Among Osteopathic Medical Students who Take Both Examinations|journal=Teaching and Learning in Medicine|date=22 January 2010|volume=22|issue=1|pages=3–7|pmid=20391276|doi=10.1080/10401330903445422}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation Residency Program Director's Manual|url=http://www.acgme.org/acgmeweb/Portals/0/PFAssets/ProgramResources/340_Director_Manual_Revised_2011.pdf|publisher=Association of Academic Physiatrists|accessdate=2016-12-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbome.org/directors-faq.asp |title=Program Directors FAQ |publisher=NBOME |accessdate=2012-02-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807005745/http://www.nbome.org/directors-faq.asp |archive-date=2011-08-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> USMLE pass rates for DO and MD students in 2012 are as follows: Step 1: 91% and 94%, Step 2 CK: 96% and 97%, and Step 2 CS: 87% and 97%, respectively (this number may be misleading as only 46 DO students compared to 17,118 MD students were evaluated for Step 2 CS) Step 3: 100% and 95% (this number may be misleading, as only 16 DO students compared to 19,056 MD students, were evaluated for Step 3).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbme.org/PDF/Publications/2012Annual-Report.pdf |title=2012 Annual Report |date=2012 |publisher=National Board of Medical Examiners |accessdate=20 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509144605/http://www.nbme.org/PDF/Publications/2012Annual-Report.pdf |archivedate=9 May 2013 |df= }}</ref>
{{further|Comparison of MD and DO in the United States}}
== Licensing and board certification == To obtain a license to practice medicine in the United States, osteopathic medical students must pass the [[Comprehensive Osteopathic Medical Licensing Examination]] (COMLEX),<ref>{{cite web|title=Board Examinations and Licensure|url=http://www.aacom.org/resources/bookstore/cib/Documents/2012cib/2012cib-p11.pdf|work=Medical College Information Book, 2012 edition|publisher=AACOM|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> the licensure exam administered by the [[National Board of Osteopathic Medical Examiners]] throughout their medical training. Students are given the option of also taking the [[United States Medical Licensing Examination]] (USMLE) to apply for some [[Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education]] (ACGME) residency programs. Those that have received or are in the process of earning an MD or DO degree are both eligible to sit for the USMLE. Because of their additional training, only DO candidates are eligible to sit for the COMLEX.<ref>{{cite web|title=COMLEX-USA: Bulletin of Information|url=http://www.nbome.org/docs/comlexboi.pdf|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120916080523/http://www.nbome.org/docs/comlexBOI.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=16 September 2012|publisher=National Board of Osteopathic Medical Examiners|accessdate=19 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Upon completion of internship and residency requirements for their chosen medical specialty, and depending on whether the program attended as ACGME or AOA accredited, holders of the DO may elect to be board certified by either a specialty board (through the [[American Medical Association]]'s [[American Board of Medical Specialties]]) or an osteopathic specialty board (through the [[American Osteopathic Association Bureau of Osteopathic Specialists]] certifying boards). In February 2014, the [[American Osteopathic Association]] and the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education agreed to unify allopathic and osteopathic [[Graduate medical education]] starting in 2020.<ref>{{cite web|title=Allopathic and Osteopathic Medical Communities Commit to a Single Graduate Medical Education Accreditation System|url=https://www.acgme.org/acgmeweb/portals/0/PDFS/Nasca-Community/SingleAccreditationRelease2-26.pdf|publisher=Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education|accessdate=3 March 2014}}</ref>
Depending on the state, medical licensure may be issued from a combined board (DO and MD) or a separate board of medical examiners.<ref name=DirectoryBoards>{{cite web|title=Directory of State Medical and Osteopathic Boards|url=http://www.fsmb.org/directory_smb.html|publisher=Federation of State Medical Boards|accessdate=6 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120709175748/http://www.fsmb.org/directory_smb.html|archivedate=9 July 2012|df=}}</ref> All of the 70 state medical boards are members of the [[Federation of State Medical Boards]].<ref name=FSMB>{{cite web|title=Federation of State Medical Boards|url=http://www.fsmb.org/index.html|publisher=Federation of State Medical Boards|accessdate=18 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115063540/http://www.fsmb.org/index.html|archivedate=15 November 2012|df=}}</ref>
== International variations == Currently, there are no osteopathic programs located outside of the United States that would qualify an individual to practice as an osteopathic physician in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aacom.org/about/osteomed/Pages/TheDifference.aspx |title=The Difference Between U.S.-Trained Osteopathic Physicians and Osteopaths Trained Abroad |date=2012 |publisher=American Association of Colleges of Osteopathic Medicine |accessdate=17 December 2012}}</ref> Foreign osteopathic degrees are not recognized by any state in the US as being equivalent to American DO degrees.
=== International practice rights === The following is an international licensure summary for US-trained doctors of osteopathic medicine, as listed by the [[American Osteopathic Association]]:<ref>[https://archive.is/20130415125945/http://www.osteopathic.org/osteopathic-health/about-dos/dos-around-the-world/Pages/frequently-asked-questions.aspx ''Frequently Asked Questions regarding International Licensure'', Council on International Osteopathic Medical Education & Affairs, American Osteopathic Association]. Contact information listed.</ref><ref name=InternationalRights>{{cite web|title=AOA International Licensure Summary|url=http://www.osteopathic.org/inside-aoa/development/licensure/Documents/AOA_International_Licensure_Summary_2013.pdf|publisher=American Osteopathic Association|date=April 2013}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- |+AOA International Licensure Summary.<ref name=InternationalRights /> |- ! style="width:85pt;" colspan="2"| Country ! style="width:85pt;"| Year of Latest Policy ! style="width:85pt;"| Medical Practice Rights ! Requirements for Licensure |- | colspan="2"|Argentina |2006 |Unlimited |Foreign physicians must submit credentials to various agencies and then appear before any of the National Universities in order to have their diploma recognized. |- | colspan="2"| Australia |2013 |Unlimited |According to documents published online, the Medical Board of Australia has "agreed to accept the DO USA as a primary medical qualification for the purposes of medical registration provided that the DO USA was awarded by a medical school which has been accredited by the [[Commission on Osteopathic College Accreditation]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=FAQ and Fact Sheets|url=http://www.medicalboard.gov.au/Codes-Guidelines-Policies/FAQ.aspx|work=AHPRA|publisher=Medical Board of Australia}}</ref> |- | colspan="2"| Austria |2009 |Unlimited |Hospital must have position unable to be filled by Austrian physician. |- | colspan="2"| Bahamas |2004 |Unlimited |US license recognized. |- | colspan="2"| Bahrain |2010 |Unlimited |US license recognized. |- | colspan="2"| Barbados |1995 |Limited |[[Osteopathic manipulative medicine]] (OMM) only. |- | colspan="2"| Belize |2009 |Unlimited |Must complete a Belizean residency for permanent license eligibility. |- | colspan="2"| Bermuda |1997 |Unlimited |Required at least 2 years of GME and examination or interview by the Council's Examination Committee. Non-Bermudans must have approval from the Ministry of Labour & Home Affairs to work on the island. |- | colspan="2"| Brazil |2007 |Unlimited |Completion of Brazilian board exam, establishing residency & some training in Brazilian hospital is required. |- | rowspan="12" | Canada |Alberta | |Unlimited |Requires at least 2 years of GME accredited by the [[ACGME]] or AOA and must have passed the Universities Coordinating Council Exam, a basic sciences exam, and have passed all three parts of the [[Licentiate of the Medical Council of Canada|LMCC]]. |- |British Columbia | |Unlimited |Requires at least 1 year of GME approved by the AOA or the ACGME, completed at least 1 year of GME in Canada, passed all three parts of the LMCC. |- |Manitoba | |Unlimited |US license recognized. |- |New Brunswick | |Unlimited |Requires at least 2 years of GME approved by the AOA or the ACGME and have passed all 3 parts of the LMCC. Reciprocity pathway for DO physicians with a Maine license. |- |Newfoundland | |Unlimited |The Medical Act 2011 allows full licensure of osteopathic physicians, both for the country's full registry & its educational registry. |- |NW Territories | |Unlimited |US license recognized. |- |Nova Scotia | |Unlimited |Requires a Canadian or ACGME residency. |- |Ontario | |Unlimited |Requires a Canadian or ACGME residency. |- |Prince Edward Island | |Unlimited | |- |Quebec | |Unlimited |Requires 1 year of GME approved by the AOA or ACGME, 1 year of GME in Quebec passed the written, oral and clinical board examination of the College of Family Physicians of Canada and must speak French fluently. |- |Saskatchewan | |Unlimited |- |Yukon Territory | |Unlimited |US license recognized. |- | colspan="2"| Cayman Islands (UK) |1983 |Unlimited |US license recognized. |- | colspan="2"| Central African Republic |1990 |Unlimited |US licensure and annual attendance at the National Congress for Physicians. |- | colspan="2"| Chile |2008 |Unlimited |A written exam in Spanish is required, besides a series of practical tests involving common procedures (CPR, intubation, lumbar puncture, etc.). |- | colspan="2"| China |2009 |Unlimited |United States DO physicians are permitted to apply for short-term medical practice licensure. |- | colspan="2"| Colombia |1996 |Unlimited |Same requirements as other foreign physicians. |- | colspan="2"| Costa Rica |2009 |Unlimited |Same requirements as other foreign physicians. |- | colspan="2"| Dominican Republic |2000 |Unlimited |US license & board certification recognized. |- | colspan="2"| Ecuador |1990 |Unlimited |Same requirements as other foreign physicians. Reciprocity exists with most Latin American countries. |- | colspan="2"| Ethiopia |2011 |Unlimited |Must renew the license every 5 years. |- | colspan="2"| Finland |1996 |Unlimited |Same requirements as other foreign physicians. |- | colspan="2"|France |2009 |Limited |OMM only. The French government does not recognize the full scope of practice osteopathic medicine. |- | colspan="2"|The Gambia |2011 |Unlimited | |- | colspan="2"|Germany |2008 |Unlimited |Same requirements as other foreign physicians. Depends on need. Decisions made on individual basis. |- | colspan="2"|Greece |2009 |Unlimited |Greek citizenship required, unless, in rare instances, there exists a crucial need for certain types of specialist physicians. Further, a work permit must be obtained, a difficult task, and speaking Greek is an unwritten requirement. These are the same requirements as other foreign physicians. |- | colspan="2"|Grenada |2007 |Unlimited |US license recognized. |- | colspan="2"|Guyana |1996 |Unlimited |Case-by case basis. |- | colspan="2"|Honduras |2009 |Unlimited |National Autonomous University must accredit all foreign titles. After accreditation is completed, the applicant must seek registration with the Medical College of Honduras (MCH). |- | colspan="2"|Hong Kong |1998 |Unlimited |Written examination. Personal interview. Training approval. |- | colspan="2"|India |2012 |Unlimited |Unlimited for short-term work. |- | colspan="2"|Indonesia |1992 |Unlimited and restricted |Foreign physicians affiliated with a university project or a mission have unlimited practice rights. No private practice allowed. |- | colspan="2"|Iran |2009 |Unlimited |Iranian citizens who have received both the DO degree from a US osteopathic school and are board certified in a clinical specialty. Osteopathic degrees from other countries are not accepted. The process of evaluation of the medical education and clinical training is under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Health and Medical Education (MoHME). |- | colspan="2"|Israel |2007 |Unlimited |Same requirements as other foreign physicians. Hebrew required. |- | colspan="2"|Italy |2009 |Unlimited |Physicians are discouraged from seeking employment in Italy without firm contracts and work permits. If there is a US state law outlining reciprocity with Italy, a statement to this effect from the Italian Consulate will warrant better chances. |- | colspan="2"|Jamaica |1994 |Limited and restricted |DO physicians were permitted to supply some services while participating in a specific mission project. |- | colspan="2"|Jordan |2012 |Unlimited | |- | colspan="2"|Kenya | 2007 |Unlimited | |- | colspan="2"|Lebanon |2004 |Unlimited |AOA letter required. Examination required. |- | colspan="2"|Lesotho |1990s |Unlimited |Applicants must appear before the Medical, Dental and Pharmacy Council to answer some medical questions and present their credentials. The Council will also make a recommendation about where the applicant's skills would be most helpful in the country. |- | colspan="2"|Liberia |1990s |Unlimited |Same requirements as other foreign physicians. |- | colspan="2"|Luxembourg |1987 |Unlimited |The practice of medicine in Luxembourg by a doctor who is not an EU national is very rare. |- | colspan="2"|Malta |2010 |Unlimited |Accepted on a case by case basis if training meets the minimum educational requirements for physicians in the EU (Article 24 of Directive 2005/36/EC). Examination required. |- | colspan="2"|Malawi |1991 |Unlimited | |- | colspan="2"|Mexico |2011 |Unlimited & Restricted |Health Secretary Quijano of the Yucatán State of Mexico signed a Proclamation recognizing US-trained osteopathic physicians in that state; DO physicians can now obtain short-term & long-term licensure through the Health Secretary's office. All other Mexican states require work permits - only available in conjunction with the association of a short-term medical mission project. |- | colspan="2"|Micronesia |1993 |Unlimited |Statutes specifically include DOs |- | colspan="2"|Nepal |2008 |Unlimited |Approval by the Nepal Medical Council & a visa from the Immigration Department. |- | colspan="2"|Netherlands |2009 |Unlimited |Same requirements as other foreign physicians. |- | colspan="2"|New Zealand |2008 |Unlimited |Hearing required. Case-by-case basis. |- | colspan="2"|Nigeria |2010 |Unlimited |US licensure and completion of specialty training required. |- | colspan="2"|Norway |2009 |Limited |OMM only, but DOs may apply for recognition as medical doctors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Norway: Osteopathic Medicine|url=http://wp.oialliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/norway_om.pdf|publisher=Osteopathic International Alliance}}</ref> |- | colspan="2"|Pakistan |2011 |Unlimited |US osteopathic medical schools meet the Medical and Dental Council's statutory regulations for international medical graduates. Scope is unlimited, but practice setting may be restricted |- | colspan="2"|Panama |2009 |Unlimited |Panamanian citizenship required. |- | colspan="2"|Papua New Guinea |2010 |Unlimited |Work permit required. Short-term or a long-term volunteer service license also available. |- | colspan="2"|Peru |2011 |Unlimited |Process for licensure is the same as for other IMGs. |- | colspan="2"|Poland |2009 |Unlimited |Examination & Polish required. |- | colspan="2"|Qatar |2011 |Unlimited |Must possess a valid work visa, and pass written and oral examinations. |- | colspan="2"|Russia |2006 |Unlimited |Foreign physicians make arrangements to practice through Russian sponsors, such as hospitals or businesses. |- | colspan="2"|Saint Lucia |2000 |Unlimited |US credentials recognized. |- | colspan="2"|Saudi Arabia |2009 |Unlimited |Foreign physician must be recruited by a government agency, a corporation or a private health care entity, such as a hospital. |- | colspan="2"|Sierra Leone |1993 |Unlimited |Notarized US credentials recognized. |- | colspan="2"|South Africa |2009 |Limited |OMM only |- | colspan="2"|Sweden |2005 |Unlimited |US license recognized. |- | colspan="2"|Taiwan |2008 |Unlimited |The [[Republic of China|ROC]] government recognizes American DO degrees. Applicants must take Taiwan Examination Yuan to obtain Taiwanese license. |- | colspan="2"|Tanzania |1985 |Unlimited |US license and GME recognized. Temporary work permits are available |- | colspan="2"|Uganda |2008 |Unlimited | |- | colspan="2"|United Arab Emirates |2009 |Unlimited |Examination required. |- | colspan="2"|United Kingdom |2005 |Unlimited |US-trained DO physicians are eligible for full medical practice rights. Applicants must pass the [[Professional and Linguistic Assessment Board test|PLAB]] examination and work for one year in the [[National Health Service]]. Following that year, the applicants will be able to apply for a license to practice privately. For GMC registration as a specialist, postgraduate training will need to be separately recognized by the Postgraduate Medical Education and Training Board (PMETB). GOsC registration is also required. |- | colspan="2"|Venezuela |2007 |Unlimited |Recognized status under the law of the practice of medicine. |- | colspan="2"|Vietnam |1995 |Unlimited |Foreign physicians can fill vacancies in hospitals that are in need of certain specialists. |- | colspan="2"|Zambia |2009 |Unlimited |US licensure required. |- | colspan="2"|Zimbabwe |2009 |Limited |OMM only. |- |colspan="5" | '''OMM: [[Osteopathic Manipulative Medicine]]''' |}

revision.text:
The '''European Pathway Association''' (E-P-A.org) is a [[Europe]]an [[non-profit]] organisation which brings together researchers, managers and clinicians on the management concept of [[Clinical Pathway|clinical pathways]]. The organisation works on the establishment of [[Clinical Pathway|clinical care pathways]] in order to systematically plan and follow up a patient focused [[Health care|care]] program.
==History== In 2003, at the conference of the ''International Society for Quality in Healthcare'' (ISQUA) in [[Dallas]] (United States), the idea of a European Pathway Association was suggested by Kris Vanhaecht of the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] (Belgium) and Massimiliano Panella of the [[University of Eastern Piedmont]] (Italy). On 16 and 17 September 2004, the EPA was founded at a meeting in [[Jesi]] (Italy).
==See also== * [[European Institute for Health Records]]
==References== * Darer J, Pronovost P, Bass E. Use and evaluation of critical pathways in hospitals. Eff Clin Pract 2002; 5:114-119. * De Luc K., ''Developing care pathways - the handbook'', Oxford: Radcliffe Medical Press Ltd, 2001. * Vanhaecht K, Bollmann M, Bower K, Gallagher C, Gardini A, Guezo J et al., ''International survey on the use and dissemination of clinical pathways in 23 countries'', Journal of Integrated Care Pathways, 2006.
==External links== * [http://www.e-p-a.org/ European Pathway Association]
